messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write tests with the prefix test_.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
Write complete MVC code for the following system design task. Design Dropbox or Google Drive (A Global File Storage and Sharing Service)
Design a file hosting service that allows users to upload, store, share, delete, and download files on their servers and provides synchronization across various devices.
Features to implement: 
1. Ability to upload / view / search / share / download files.
2. ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability) properties should be present in the system.
3. Approach to track permission for file sharing.
4. Allowing multiple users to edit the same document.
5. The system should support storing large files up to a GB.
```

Understand the problem, by creating a detailed step-by-step plan. Try to solve the problem in the minimal steps necessary, in no more than 10 steps. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. The last step should be running any tests automatically if they exist, and the penultimate step writing these tests. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "Step 1: Identify the core components of the system. These will include User, File, and Sharing classes. The User class will handle user-related operations such as login, logout, and registration. The File class will handle file-related operations such as upload, download, view, and delete. The Sharing class will handle file sharing operations such as share and unshare. Each class will have its own methods to perform these operations.",
    "Step 2: Design the User class. This class will have methods for user registration, login, and logout. It will also have a method to get the user's files. The User class will have attributes such as username, password, and a list of files.",
    "Step 3: Design the File class. This class will have methods for file upload, download, view, and delete. It will also have a method to get the file's metadata. The File class will have attributes such as file name, file size, file type, and file content.",
    "Step 4: Design the Sharing class. This class will have methods for file sharing and unsharing. It will also have a method to get the shared files. The Sharing class will have attributes such as the file to be shared, the user who shared the file, and the users with whom the file is shared.",
    "Step 5: Implement the ACID properties in the system. This can be achieved by using a database management system that supports ACID properties. The system will need to handle transactions to ensure that the ACID properties are maintained.",
    "Step 6: Implement the approach to track permission for file sharing. This can be achieved by adding a permissions attribute to the File class. The permissions attribute will be a list of users who have permission to view and edit the file.",
    "Step 7: Implement the feature to allow multiple users to edit the same document. This can be achieved by using a version control system. The system will need to handle conflicts when multiple users try to edit the same document at the same time.",
    "Step 8: Implement the feature to support storing large files up to a GB. This can be achieved by using a file system that supports large files. The system will need to handle file splitting and merging for large files.",
    "Step 9: Write tests for each class and method. The tests should cover all the features of the system. Use pytest for writing the tests.",
    "Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Ensure that all the tests pass before considering the system to be fully functional."
  ]
}

messages.content:
Objective: Execute task step: Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Ensure that all the tests pass before considering the system to be fully functional. 

 Note: Condition any new code files on the existing code files: ['user.py', 'file.py', 'sharing.py', 'database.py', 'test_user.py', 'test_file.py', 'test_sharing.py']. You can now optionally view the existing files if you need to view them to complete the current task step. You have a limited context window so be selective about which files you view, only view the files you think you might need to view.

messages.name: view_files
messages.content:
{"files": "sharing.py
```python
from database import Database

class Sharing:
	def __init__(self, file, shared_by, shared_with):
		self.file = file
		self.shared_by = shared_by
		self.shared_with = shared_with
		self.db = Database('file_storage.db')

	def share(self):
		query = 'INSERT INTO sharing (file, shared_by, shared_with) VALUES (?, ?, ?)'
		params = (self.file, self.shared_by, self.shared_with)
		self.db.execute_query(query, params)
		self.db.commit_transaction()

	def unshare(self):
		# Unshare logic goes here
		pass

	def get_shared_files(self):
		# Logic to get shared files goes here
		return self.shared_with
```

"}

steps: Step 1: Identify the core components of the system. These will include User, File, and Sharing classes. The User class will handle user-related operations such as login, logout, and registration. The File class will handle file-related operations such as upload, download, view, and delete. The Sharing class will handle file sharing operations such as share and unshare. Each class will have its own methods to perform these operations.

Step 2: Design the User class. This class will have methods for user registration, login, and logout. It will also have a method to get the user's files. The User class will have attributes such as username, password, and a list of files.

Step 3: Design the File class. This class will have methods for file upload, download, view, and delete. It will also have a method to get the file's metadata. The File class will have attributes such as file name, file size, file type, and file content.

Step 4: Design the Sharing class. This class will have methods for file sharing and unsharing. It will also have a method to get the shared files. The Sharing class will have attributes such as the file to be shared, the user who shared the file, and the users with whom the file is shared.

Step 5: Implement the ACID properties in the system. This can be achieved by using a database management system that supports ACID properties. The system will need to handle transactions to ensure that the ACID properties are maintained.

Step 6: Implement the approach to track permission for file sharing. This can be achieved by adding a permissions attribute to the File class. The permissions attribute will be a list of users who have permission to view and edit the file.

Step 7: Implement the feature to allow multiple users to edit the same document. This can be achieved by using a version control system. The system will need to handle conflicts when multiple users try to edit the same document at the same time.

Step 8: Implement the feature to support storing large files up to a GB. This can be achieved by using a file system that supports large files. The system will need to handle file splitting and merging for large files.
Step 9: Write tests for each class and method. The tests should cover all the features of the system. Use pytest for writing the tests.
Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Ensure that all the tests pass before considering the system to be fully functional.
step: Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Ensure that all the tests pass before considering the system to be fully functional.

Write complete MVC code for the following system design task. Design Dropbox or Google Drive (A Global File Storage and Sharing Service)
Design a file hosting service that allows users to upload, store, share, delete, and download files on their servers and provides synchronization across various devices.
Features to implement: 
1. Ability to upload / view / search / share / download files.
2. ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability) properties should be present in the system.
3. Approach to track permission for file sharing.
4. Allowing multiple users to edit the same document.
5. The system should support storing large files up to a GB.
```

Understand the problem, by creating a detailed step-by-step plan. Try to solve the problem in the minimal steps necessary, in no more than 10 steps. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. The last step should be running any tests automatically if they exist, and the penultimate step writing these tests. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "Step 1: Identify the core components of the system. These will include User, File, and Sharing classes. The User class will handle user-related operations such as login, logout, and registration. The File class will handle file-related operations such as upload, download, view, and delete. The Sharing class will handle file sharing operations such as share and unshare. Each class will have its own methods to perform these operations.",
    "Step 2: Design the User class. This class will have methods for user registration, login, and logout. It will also have a method to get the user's files. The User class will have attributes such as username, password, and a list of files.",
    "Step 3: Design the File class. This class will have methods for file upload, download, view, and delete. It will also have a method to get the file's metadata. The File class will have attributes such as file name, file size, file type, and file content.",
    "Step 4: Design the Sharing class. This class will have methods for file sharing and unsharing. It will also have a method to get the shared files. The Sharing class will have attributes such as the file to be shared, the user who shared the file, and the users with whom the file is shared.",
    "Step 5: Implement the ACID properties in the system. This can be achieved by using a database management system that supports ACID properties. The system will need to handle transactions to ensure that the ACID properties are maintained.",
    "Step 6: Implement the approach to track permission for file sharing. This can be achieved by adding a permissions attribute to the File class. The permissions attribute will be a list of users who have permission to view and edit the file.",
    "Step 7: Implement the feature to allow multiple users to edit the same document. This can be achieved by using a version control system. The system will need to handle conflicts when multiple users try to edit the same document at the same time.",
    "Step 8: Implement the feature to support storing large files up to a GB. This can be achieved by using a file system that supports large files. The system will need to handle file splitting and merging for large files.",
    "Step 9: Write tests for each class and method. The tests should cover all the features of the system. Use pytest for writing the tests.",
    "Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Ensure that all the tests pass before considering the system to be fully functional."
  ]
}

sub_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write tests with the prefix test_.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest

sub_messages.content:
{"files": "sharing.py
```python
from database import Database

class Sharing:
	def __init__(self, file, shared_by, shared_with):
		self.file = file
		self.shared_by = shared_by
		self.shared_with = shared_with
		self.db = Database('file_storage.db')

	def share(self):
		query = 'INSERT INTO sharing (file, shared_by, shared_with) VALUES (?, ?, ?)'
		params = (self.file, self.shared_by, self.shared_with)
		self.db.execute_query(query, params)
		self.db.commit_transaction()

	def unshare(self):
		# Unshare logic goes here
		pass

	def get_shared_files(self):
		# Logic to get shared files goes here
		return self.shared_with
```

"}
